Those are orthogonal concern. The manifest defines which of the assets ough=
t to be made available offline, aka persisted in the cache for a duration t=
hat is not tied to the duration of the max-age but of the installed app. *T=
hat said*, the behavior in deciding to do a conditional request or not base=
d on existing caching validation function would make a lot of sense.

More =
so, it makes a lot of sense for an app that can be used both offline and on=
line to have the caching semantics sematics of resources being present and =
respected, for until a user "installs" the app, the app will react like any=
 HTTP application.

For me, appCache can (and probably ought to) simply ext=
end and override the semantics of caching controls to ensure that whatever =
caching sematics, the cached (and maybe stale) resource state  is available=
 for however long the application is installed.

ubject: RE: [rest-discuss] Is HTML5 cache a useless regression?

>> Ok, but=
 this doesn't address why they need to invent an
>> entirely separate cache=
-control mechanism, instead of
>> reusing and extending what we already hav=
e around HTTP.
>>
>> The stale-if-error directive introduced by the Cache-C=
ontrol
>> Extensions for Stale Content[1] already gives us most of
>> what =
they are trying to achieve.
>
> *Boom*, that's exactly my point.

It's diff=
erent I would say. The app cache is really for applications. You
include al=
l your app assets and code and then "install" it. It doesn't make
that much=
 sense to have parts with different lifetimes in such a scenario
and the ma=
nifest is more or less just a way to create a package. It also
gives you AP=
Is to check the state of your cache and so on..

How else would you achieve=
 that in a browser? Since the browser doesn't know
what belongs together it=
 would probably delete a huge JS file at some point
while still keeping the=
 other stuff. This would break your app. So perhaps
think of it more in ter=
ms of an app than in terms of caching.
